title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify the profit-maximizing quantity as 24 units and/or does not explain that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.
The response identifies the profit-maximizing quantity as 24 units and explains that at that quantity marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that the firm earns negative economic profit and/or does not explain that the firm’s average total cost curve is above the demand curve, or the firm charges a price that is less than the average total cost, or ATC > P MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E37@ .

The response states that the firm earns negative economic profit and explains that the firm’s average total cost curve is above the demand curve, or the firm charges a price that is less than the average total cost, or ATC > P MathType@MTEF@5@5@@3E37@ .

title: Part C
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate MemorEyes’s total revenue at the allocatively efficient quantity as $3,030 and/or does not show the work.

Total Revenue=Price×Quantity=$101×30=$3,030 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5FD2@

The response calculates MemorEyes’s total revenue at the allocatively efficient quantity as $3,030 and shows the work.

Total Revenue=Price×Quantity=$101×30=$3,030 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@5FD2@

title: Part D
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that at that price ($40) the firm will shut down in the short run and/or does not explain it’s because the price is below the average variable cost which means the firm does not generate enough revenue to pay for its variable costs so the firm loses more by producing, in the short run, than shutting down and just paying its fixed cost.

The response states that at that price ($40) the firm will shut down in the short run and explains it’s because the price is below the average variable cost which means the firm does not generate enough revenue to pay for its variable costs so the firm loses more by producing, in the short run, than shutting down and just paying its fixed cost.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not calculate the new average total cost as $135 and/or does not show the work.

New ATC= Original Total Cost+Increase in Total Cost Quantity = $120×30+$450 30 =$135 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7D63@

or

New ATC=Original Average Total Cost+ Increase in Total Cost Quantity =$120+ $450 30 =$135 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@80C8@

The response calculates the new average total cost as $135 and shows the work.

New ATC= Original Total Cost+Increase in Total Cost Quantity = $120×30+$450 30 =$135 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@7D63@

or

New ATC=Original Average Total Cost+ Increase in Total Cost Quantity =$120+ $450 30 =$135 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@80C8@

title: Part F
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that no, Cognitz does not have dominant strategy and/or does not explain that when MemorEyes lowers its price, Cognitz’s payoff is higher if it does not advertise ( $3400> $2500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4154@ ), and when MemorEyes maintains its price, Cognitz’s payoff is higher when it chooses to advertise ( $8500> $6500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@415E@ ); therefore, Cognitz does not have a dominant strategy.

The response states that no, Cognitz does not have dominant strategy and explains that when MemorEyes lowers its price, Cognitz’s payoff is higher if it does not advertise ( $3,400> $2,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B2@ ), and when MemorEyes maintains its price, Cognitz’s payoff is higher when it chooses to advertise ( $8,500> $6,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42BC@ ); therefore, Cognitz does not have a dominant strategy.

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not identify Nash equilibrium as MemorEyes lowers its price and Cognitz does not advertise with payoffs of ($3,000, $3,400) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43F3@ , and/or does not explain that if MemorEyes chooses to maintain its price, its payoff will decrease from $3,000 to $2,000, and if Cognitz chooses to advertise, its payoff will decrease from $3,400 to $2,500; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response identifies Nash equilibrium as MemorEyes lowers its price and Cognitz does not advertise with payoffs of ($3,000, $3,400) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43F3@ , and explains that if MemorEyes chooses to maintain its price, its payoff will decrease from $3,000 to $2,000, and if Cognitz chooses to advertise, its payoff will decrease from $3,400 to $2,500; therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions: The response does not state that yes, this offer will result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and/or does not explain that the new strategies will be for MemorEyes to maintain its price and Cognitz to advertise with payoffs of ($4,500, $7,000) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43F9@ because with the offer MemorEyes would earn $4,500 ( =$3,000 + $1,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43FD@ ) when choosing to maintain the price compared to $4,000 (with lower price), and Cognitz would earn $7,000 ( =$8,500−$1,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42FF@ ) when choosing to advertise compared to $5,000 ( =$6,500−$1,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42FD@ with not advertising); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy. Or explain that with the offer MemorEyes’ dominant strategy will change to maintain the price because its payoff will always be higher $3,500> $3,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42AF@ and $4,500> $4,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B1@ ) and since Cognitz has no dominant strategy it is better off to advertise $7,000 > $5,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4353@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.

The response states that yes, this offer will result in a Nash equilibrium with different strategies and explains that the new strategies will be for MemorEyes to maintain its price and Cognitz to advertise with payoffs of ($4,500, $7,000) MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43F9@ because with the offer MemorEyes would earn $4,500 ( =$3,000 + $1,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@43FD@ ) when choosing to maintain the price compared to $4,000 (with lower price), and Cognitz would earn $7,000 ( =$8,500−$1,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42FF@ ) when choosing to advertise compared to $5,000 ( =$6,500−$1,500 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42FD@ with not advertising); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy. Or explains that with the offer MemorEyes’ dominant strategy will change to maintain the price because its payoff will always be higher $3,500> $3,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42AF@ and $4,500> $4,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@42B1@ ) and since Cognitz has no dominant strategy it is better off to advertise $7,000 > $5,000 MathType@MTEF@5@5@@4353@ ); therefore, there is no incentive for either firm to change its strategy.
